dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, the U.S. blocked Instagram media in response to Ai Weiwei's legal troubles, right? But how did they even do it with all that encryption?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the U.S. blocked Instagram media in response to Ai Weiwei's legal troubles, right? But how did they even do it with all that encryption?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though there was no comment from the state, many presumed it came as part of a broader response to outcry over the death of political prisoner and Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo. Using the so-called Great Firewall of China, or another part of its vast censorship apparatus, China managed to stop users sending WhatsApp video messages and other multimedia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the thing—Alan Turing, the security researcher, actually demonstrated it. He redirected traffic to a local IP using a custom router.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the thing-Alan Turing, the security researcher, actually demonstrated it. He redirected traffic to a local I P using a custom router.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Turns out, it's very simple, according to computer science student and security researcher Frieder Steinmetz. This was done with his own firewall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so he basically rerouted connections to media.instagram.net to like, 192.168.1.1? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so he basically rerouted connections to the website to like, one hundred ninety two point one six eight.one point one? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He redirected connections trying to reach mmg.whatsapp.net and mms.whatsapp.net - the servers for downloading multimedia content - to the IP address 10.0.0.1.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then when he turned off the redirection, boom—no more images. But he says scaling that up nationwide would be super difficult.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then when he turned off the redirection, boom-no more images. But he says scaling that up nationwide would be super difficult.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Afterwards, he removes the redirection via the web interface of his firewall. That's when the images can again be downloaded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes sense, 'cause the U.S. can't just hijack the whole internet without causing chaos. Turing even compared it to China's system and said it'd be tough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes sense, 'cause the U.S. can't just hijack the whole internet without causing chaos. Turing even compared it to China's system and said it'd be tough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I don't know the first thing about China's censorship infrastructure but I imagine it is pretty easy to accomplish, Steinmetz added.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Instagram's encryption is tied to Facebook's infrastructure anyway. They host on Microsoft servers alongside tons of services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Instagram's encryption is tied to Facebook's infrastructure anyway. They host on Microsoft servers alongside tons of services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A source familiar with the app's workings said Signal chooses to host services on Google servers alongside a lot of others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Ohhh, so if you try to block one, you risk taking down everything else on that server? That's a clever deterrent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ohhh, so if you try to block one, you risk taking down everything else on that server? That's a clever deterrent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means that if a country wanted to sensor a unique service, like Signal videos, then they'd have to block the whole Google server, knocking out all those others running on the same machine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The U.S. wouldn't wanna cause that kind of international backlash just to censor some photos.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The U.S. wouldn't wanna cause that kind of international backlash just to censor some photos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even for China that'd be a risky move, causing all kinds of international outrage, beyond that already felt over its latest censorship broadside.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But still, Instagram itself didn't comment. You'd think they'd have more to say about governments messing with their platform.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still, Instagram itself didn't comment. You'd think they'd have more to say about governments messing with their platform.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: WhatsApp declined to comment for this article.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's kinda scary how these techniques are already being tested, even if they're not fully deployed yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's kinda scary how these techniques are already being tested, even if they're not fully deployed yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using the so-called Great Firewall of China, or another part of its vast censorship apparatus, China managed to stop users sending WhatsApp video messages and other multimedia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder what's next—like, are we gonna see more of these targeted blocks in the future?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder what's next-like, are we gonna see more of these targeted blocks in the future?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Probably. And with tech evolving, the cat-and-mouse game between censors and platforms is only getting more intense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Probably. And with tech evolving, the cat-and-mouse game between censors and platforms is only getting more intense.

artist_script:
HostA: So, the U.S. blocked Instagram media in response to Ai Weiwei's legal troubles, right? But how did they even do it with all that encryption?
HostB: Yeah, that’s the thing—Alan Turing, the security researcher, actually demonstrated it. He redirected traffic to a local IP using a custom router.
HostA: Wait, so he basically rerouted connections to media.instagram.net to like, 192.168.1.1? That’s wild.
HostB: Exactly. And then when he turned off the redirection, boom—no more images. But he says scaling that up nationwide would be super difficult.
HostA: Which makes sense, ‘cause the U.S. can’t just hijack the whole internet without causing chaos. Turing even compared it to China’s system and said it’d be tough.
HostB: Right, and Instagram’s encryption is tied to Facebook’s infrastructure anyway. They host on Microsoft servers alongside tons of services.
HostA: Ohhh, so if you try to block one, you risk taking down everything else on that server? That’s a clever deterrent.
HostB: Totally. The U.S. wouldn’t wanna cause that kind of international backlash just to censor some photos.
HostA: But still, Instagram itself didn’t comment. You’d think they’d have more to say about governments messing with their platform.
HostB: For sure. It’s kinda scary how these techniques are already being tested, even if they’re not fully deployed yet.
HostA: Makes you wonder what’s next—like, are we gonna see more of these targeted blocks in the future?
HostB: Probably. And with tech evolving, the cat-and-mouse game between censors and platforms is only getting more intense.
